page.description: Specify how the abstract CSS class names used in this component map to physical CSS class names in your style sheets.

section.description: The 'Class map' property is useful for tweaking certain aspects of existing styles. The overall style of a component can be set in the [Style name] property. The style that is selected in 'Style name' contains a certain number of 'physical' CSS classes that map to the 'abstract' CSS classes that are defined in each of the controls in your component. When you run a component, Alpha Anywhere automatically maps the selected physical CSS classes on to the abstract, or placeholder, classes. You can override any of these automatic class assignments by re-assigning an abstract CSS class to a new physical CSS class that you define. You can also uncheck the [Resolve abstract CSS class names] property to view the abstract class placeholders as they appear without styling. The process of setting abstract CSS class names is explained in this two part video on 'Abstract CSS Class Names': [Part 1], [Part 2]. You can also follow the guide below.

section.title: Viewing Abstract Classes in a Browser

step.description: In the UX Builder on the UX Controls page define a UX component by adding multiple types of controls to the controls tree..
Open the UX Properties page and click the [...] button next to the '[Style name]' property in the UX Properties section.
From the Location menu select 'System'. Select one of the options from the list of available styles. Click OK.
Right click and select 'Inspect Element' from the browser menu.
Click on the HTML viewing option and view an element in your component, you should see physical CSS class assignments for each element.
You should see the component displayed with the styling you specified.
Go back to Alpha Anywhere's Design tab and return to the UX Properties page. Uncheck the 'Resolve abstract CSS class names' checkbox.
Run the component again in Firefox, you should only see the rough styling of the underlying abstract CSS class.
Right click and select 'Inspect Element' from the browser menu.
Click on the HTML tab and view the class assignment for a given element. You should see the abstract class for that element.
